thread.title: Astros stun powerful field for Woods Trail Run title
thread.title_full: Astros stun powerful field for Woods Trail Run title

title: Astros stun powerful field for Woods Trail Run title
text:
Astros stun powerful field for Woods Trail Run title 
Maison D'Amelio Astros stun powerful field for Woods Trail Run title 
THETFORD, Vt. — Amy Bernard had only one thing on her mind Saturday when she took her Pinkerton girls cross country team to the talent-laden Woods Trail Run at Thetford Academy. 
“I was just mainly looking for the girls to get some experience for the New England meet (next month),” said Bernard. “We weren’t even thinking of winning it, or where we’d place.” 
Well, that experience turned out to be spectacular because the Astros responded by placing first in the 53-team field, which was loaded with some of the top teams in New England. 
Pinkerton finished first with 106 points, 17 points ahead of runner-up and perennial power Coe-Brown with Glastonbury, Conn., and Champlain Valley, Vt., coming in third and fourth respectively. Souhegan came in sixth. 
Just last week at the Manchester Invitational, the Astros were fourth, trailing Coe-Brown, Souhegan and Champlain Valley. 
The Astros had an impressive pack in the race. Sophomore Maison D’Amelio led a 17-18-19 finish in 20:15.94 over the rough and hilly Thetford Academy course with freshman Jordan Vaillancourt and senior Morgan Sansing right behind. Senior Ariel Vaillancourt was 26th in 20:27.08 and freshman Ciara April was 35th in 20:45,23. 
At Manchester last week, Jordan Vaillancourt ran in the freshman race, taking top honors, as did April. Saturday, they helped give the Astros the title in the largest field in Bernard’s 13 years as head coach. 
“Jordan’s just getting better and better but the top five all ran great today,” said Bernard. “To have them that close together was great.” 
Led by Exeter sophomore Jacqueline Gaughan, the top four runners in the girls race were from New Hampshire. Gaughan was first in 19:11.02 followed by Coe-Brown star Elisabeth Danis (19:22.90), Bedford’s Leya Salis and Merrimack Valley’s Kristie Schoffield. 
Kimball takes sixth 
Timberlane senior Liam Kimball, the New Hampshire Division 1 champion last year, finished sixth overall at the Woods Trail Run, running a 16:47.52. Randy Neish of Glastonbury was first in 16:12.87 with Cameron Daly of Inter-Lakes second in 16:29.61. 
As a team, the Owls came in 19th in the 63-team field. Amity, Conn., came in first, followed by East Greenwich, R.I. 
Girls Woods Trail Run 
at Thetford, Vt. (3.1 miles) 
Top team scores (53 teams): Pinkerton 106, Coe-Brown 123, Glastonbury, Conn. 148, Champlain Valley, Vt. 174, Haddam-Killingsworth, Conn. 217, Souhegan 275. 28. Timberlane 849 
Winner and top local finishers: 1. Jacqueline Gaughan (Exeter, N.H.) 19:11, 17. Maison D’Amelio (P) 20:15, 18. Jordan Vaillancourt (P) 20:16.53, 19. Morgan Sansing (P) 20:17.37, 26. Ariel Vaillancourt (P) 20:27.8, 35. Ciara April (P) 20:45.23, 97. Sadie Farnsworth (P) 22:15.28, 103. Olivia Mullins (T) 22:05, 130. Olivia Marshall (T) 22;27, 132. Meghan Tarr (T) 22:28 
Boys Woods Trail Run 
at Thetford, Vt. (3.1 miles) 
Top team scores (63 teams): Amity, Conn. 129, East Greenwich, R.I. 141, Glastonbury, Conn. 170, Champlain Valley, Vt. 172, 19. Timberlane 624 
Top two finishers and top Timberlane finishers: 1. Randy Neish (Glastonbury) 16:12.87, 2. Cameron Daly (Inter-Lakes, N.H.) 16:29.61, 6. Liam Kimball 16:47.52, 58. Jacob Kimball 18:07.23, 88. Niall Kimball 18:22
